contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=November 2006}} '''Norbert Brainin''', (12 March 1923 – 10 April 2005), was the first [[violin]]ist of the [[Amadeus Quartet]], one of the world's most highly regarded [[string quartet]]s.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2005/apr/11/guardianobituaries.artsobituaries Obituary: Norbert Brainin, The Guardian 11 April 2005]</ref> Because of Brainin's [[Jewish]] origin, he was driven out of [[Vienna]] after [[Hitler]]'s [[Anschluss]] of 1938, as were the violinist [[Siegmund Nissel]] and violist [[Peter Schidlof]]. Brainin and Schidlof met in a [[United Kingdom|British]] internment camp, many Jewish [[refugee]]s having had the misfortune of being confined by the British as "enemy [[Alien (law)|alien]]s" upon seeking refuge in the UK. Brainin was released after a few months, but Schidlof remained in the camp, where he met Nissel. Finally Schidlof and Nissel were released, and the three of them were able to study with violin pedagogue [[Max Rostal]], who taught them free of charge. It was through Rostal that they met cellist [[Martin Lovett]], and in 1947 they formed the Brainin Quartet, which was renamed as the [[Amadeus Quartet]] in 1948. The Amadeus was one of the most celebrated quartets of the 20th Century, and its members were awarded numerous honours, including: * Officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]], presented by the [[Queen Elizabeth II|Queen]] (1960) * Doctorates from the Universities of [[University of London|London]], [[University of York|York]], and [[University of Caracas|Caracas]]. * The highest of all [[Germany|German]] awards, the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Grand Cross of Merit]]. * [[Austrian Decoration for Science and Art|Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art]] (1974)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/VHG/XXIV/AB/AB_10542/imfname_251156.pdf | title = Reply to a parliamentary question | language = German | page=398 | trans_title = | format = pdf | accessdate = 19 October 2012 }}</ref> The quartet disbanded in 1987 upon the death of Schidlof, who was regarded as irreplaceable by the surviving members. Norbert Brainin continued to perform as a soloist, often performing with pianist [[Günter Ludwig]]. In 1992, Brainin performed a [[benefit concert]] in Washington, D.C. for then-jailed presidential candidate [[Lyndon LaRouche]].<ref>Murphy, Caryle, [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1294134.html "Fund-Raiser for LaRouche Draws Complaints at GU"], Washington Post, 12/07/1988</ref> His instruments included the "Rode" [[Giuseppe Guarneri|Guarnerius del Gesu]] of 1734, the "Chaconne" Stradivarius of 1725 and the [[Gibson Stradivarius|"Gibson" Stradivarius]] of 1713. == See also == * [[List of British Jewish entertainers]] * [http://www.gather.com/viewArticle.jsp?articleId=281474976733558 Martin Lovett remembering Norbert Brainin] == Sources == <references/> {{See also|Brainin}} {{Authority control|VIAF=49410837}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Brainin, Norbert | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 12 March 1923 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 10 April 2005 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brainin, Norbert}} [[Category:Jewish classical musicians]] [[Category:Austrian classical violinists]] [[Category:British classical violinists]] [[Category:Jewish refugees]] [[Category:Austrian refugees]] [[Category:Jews who emigrated to the United Kingdom to escape Nazism]] [[Category:Austrian emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Austrian people of Russian descent]] [[Category:Austrian Jews]] [[Category:British Jews]] [[Category:Musicians from Vienna]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Commanders Crosses of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] [[Category:Recipients of the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and Art]] [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:LaRouche movement]] [[Category:People interned in the Isle of Man during World War II]]
